thread.title: Who is Sherlock's sister? Actress Sian Brooke plays character at heart of biggest twist in hit show's history
thread.title_full: Who is Sherlock's sister? Actress Sian Brooke plays character at heart of biggest twist in hit show's history

author: Mark Jefferies
title: Who is Sherlock's sister? Actress Sian Brooke plays character at heart of biggest twist in hit show's history
text:
Who is Sherlock's sister? Actress Sian Brooke plays character at heart of biggest twist in hit show's history Sian Brooke played many characters in the second episode of the series, The Lying Detective Share Get celebs updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
The second instalment of Sherlock's latest series featured many twists but the biggest of all was - Sherlock has a sister ! 
Sian Brooke played Watson's therapist - in the opening scene and others with clear rectangular glasses - before ending the episode by shooting Dr Watson. 
Brooke also played the woman claimed to be Culverton Smith daughter - who had chips with the master detective. Viewers will also remember her as the girl on the bus from episode one who smiled at Watson. (Photo: BBC) The Sherlock twist was brilliant (Photo: BBC) Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Watson gives Sherlock a vicious beating in shock scene Share this video Watch Next Read More 
Sian Brooke is simply listed as Elizabeth in the BBC series. 
She was previously in Not Safe For Work, Inspector Lewis and Man Down. 
Channel 4 viewers will also remember her from Meadowlands. 
Brooke played Lori in the 2007 series, alongside David Morrissey. Sian Brooke (Photo: Getty Images) 
The new character called Eurus, which is the name of the Greek God of the East Wind, is set to take over as a new evil character on the drama. 
In the final scenes of Sunday’s episode, called The Lying Detective, it emerged that actress Sian Brooke had been playing three characters on screen including Watson's therapist, all of them in disguise of her real identity. (Photo: BBC) Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now The dark and dramatic trailer for the new Sherlock Share this video Watch Next 
Mark Gatiss, who plays Sherlock's brother on screen and is also the show's other co-creator, admitted they had thought about an extra sibling for Sherlock for many years. 
He said: "It started as a joke years ago there was going to be a line in the first season where we were sketching in the Holmes family. But we thought we won't do too much and thank god we didn't because it has given us this place to go. 
"This was a huge thing to cast Sian as Eurus. We said to casting to find someone who should already be a huge star who has never had the breaks." (Photo: BBC) 
It's been revealed that the hit BBC show could come to an end soon after the show’s boss admitted they didn’t want the drama to “go past” when it should finish in terms of quality. 
The opening episode of the current series attracted over eight million viewers and it continues to be a huge global hit. 
But at a Bafta screening for episode two in Cardiff - held on Sunday morning ahead of the episode - co-creator Steven Moffat admitted the third episode of the series will be a “grand old finale” type of ending, prompting questions from the audience about the possibility this could be the last ever series. (Photo: BBC) Read More 
Moffat said: “Its a big loud note at the end. I didn’t mean in the sense I will never do Sherlock Holmes again. 
“Honestly, we don’t know, that is the honest truth. 
“We still haven’t sat down and worked out what we do. 
“We are incredibly aware that this is extraordinary in terms of scale. 
“We don’t want to let go of it because it is a wonderful thing but we don’t want to keep it going past the time that it should stop.” Like us on Facebook
